title: 109_s56
content:
The "Rio Grande Natural Area Act" establishes the Rio Grande Natural Area and defines key terms like Commission and Secretary. The Rio Grande Natural Area in Colorado is established to conserve natural, historic, cultural, scientific, scenic, wildlife, and recreational resources along the Rio Grande River. The boundaries extend from the Alamosa National Wildlife Refuge to the New Mexico State border, with a 1/4 mile buffer on each side. The Secretary will create a map and legal description of the area, which will have the same legal effect as if included in the Act. The map and legal description of the Rio Grande Natural Area shall have the same legal effect as if included in the Act, with the Secretary having the authority to correct minor errors. The information will be available for public inspection at the Bureau of Land Management offices. Establishment of the Commission. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission is established to advise the Secretary on the Natural Area and prepare a management plan for non-Federal land. The Commission consists of 9 members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives from the Bureau of Land Management, Alamosa National Wildlife Refuge, Colorado Division of Wildlife, Colorado Division of Water Resources, and Rio Grande Water. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission consists of 9 members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives from various organizations. Members serve 5-year terms without compensation and must have knowledge and experience in fields related to the Natural Area. Members may be reappointed after their term ends. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission consists of 9 members appointed by the Secretary, serving 5-year terms without compensation. The Commission elects a chairperson, holds quarterly public meetings, and receives technical assistance from Federal agencies. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission consists of 9 members appointed by the Secretary, serving 5-year terms without compensation. The Commission elects a chairperson, holds quarterly public meetings, and receives technical assistance from Federal agencies. Powers of the Commission include... The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission has the authority to conduct hearings, meetings, and receive evidence as needed. They can also enter into cooperative agreements with the State of Colorado or other entities to manage non-Federal land in the Natural Area. These agreements must include procedures for notifying the Commission of any actions that may impact the management plan. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission can assist the Secretary in implementing the management plan by preserving and interpreting natural resources. They are prohibited from acquiring real property and may enter into cooperative agreements with the State of Colorado for this purpose. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission can assist in preserving State land and wildlife, increasing public awareness of natural resources, encouraging land use policies consistent with the management plan, and helping private landowners implement the plan. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission can assist in preserving State land and wildlife, increasing public awareness of natural resources, encouraging land use policies consistent with the management plan, and helping private landowners implement the plan. SEC. 6. MANAGEMENT PLAN. The Secretary and the Commission, along with relevant agencies and landowners, must prepare management plans for the Natural Area within 4 years of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will handle Federal land management, while the Commission will manage non-Federal land and submit their plan to the Secretary for approval. The Commission will submit the management plan to the Secretary for approval or disapproval. If disapproved, the Secretary will take action. If the management plan submitted by the Commission is disapproved, the Secretary must notify the Commission of the reasons for disapproval and allow them to submit revisions. The Secretary and the Commission must cooperate to ensure consistent management plans for Federal and non-Federal land. The plans should consider existing Federal, State, and local plans for preservation, restoration, and conservation of the Natural Area. Federal land management plans must comply with relevant laws and be in harmony with adjacent land management plans. The Secretary and the Commission must cooperate to ensure consistent management plans for Federal and non-Federal land, including an inventory of resources and recommendations for resource management policies to protect the Natural Area's resources and values. The Secretary is required to publish notice of the management plans in the Federal Register. SEC. 7. ADMINISTRATION OF NATURAL AREA. The Secretary administers the Federal land in the Natural Area in accordance with laws and the management plan, focusing on conservation, restoration, and protection of natural resources. Limited public recreation and scientific study are allowed, with a prohibition on water storage facilities. The Natural Area is protected with a focus on wildlife habitat, prohibiting water storage facilities, reducing roads, and limiting motorized vehicles. The Secretary is encouraged to negotiate streamflow changes beneficial to the area with relevant parties. The management plan for the Natural Area applies to private land only with the landowner's agreement. Federal land in the area is withdrawn from various activities under public land laws, mining laws, and mineral leasing laws. The Secretary has the authority to acquire land or interests in land within the Natural Area from willing sellers. The Secretary has the authority to acquire land or interests in land within the Natural Area from willing sellers through purchase, exchange, or donation. Any acquired land shall be administered according to the management plan and this Act. Section 5(d)(1) of the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act does not apply to the Natural Area. SEC. 8. EFFECT.

This Act does not conflict with the Rio Grande Compact, regulate private land in the Natural Area, impose mandatory streamflow requirements, create Federal water rights, or impose stricter water quality standards. It also allows Colorado to acquire instream flow rights within the Natural Area. SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Such sums as necessary for this Act. SEC. 10. TERMINATION OF COMMISSION. Commission ends 10 years after enactment.
